page.title: A-level Computing/AQA/Computer Components, The Stored Program Concept and the Internet/Webpage Design/Web page construction

revision.text:
{{CPTPageNavigationU2| | Next = HTML & style sheets}} {{displaytitle|title=Webpage Design: Web page construction}} Web pages are now an essential part of how many people live their lives and perform their jobs. More and more computer functions are now moving to web based applications and it is important that you are familiar with this technology. == Structure of a web page == You might have made some web sites at secondary school using [[w:WYSIWYG|WYSIWYG]] editors such as Front Page and Dreamweaver. For the A-Level Computing course we are going to take a look at the code that these editors produce, and how to structure webpages with code. Open this wikibook page in any browser and click CTRL+U in Firefox / Chrome or View -> Page Source in Internet Explorer, you should have the webpage code in front of you. {{Dbox|HTML|Hypertext Markup Language, the language used for building web pages}} All web pages have the following basic structure: * HTML - specifies that this is a web page ** Head - contains the title of the page with code and css includes ** Body - displays the main page content Which can be represented in HTML code using the following Tags: ... ... == Tags == Web pages are built out of tags. These tags define what is on the page and how it should be structured. There are two types of tags that you can use, and all tags should be written in lower case.

A Book About Computing

 On line one you can see the first type, it has an opening tag <h1> something in the middle "A book About Computing" and a closing tag</h1>. This tells us that everything between these tags should be treated as a level one heading (h1). On line two you can see the second type of tag, there is no closing tag, the tag is entirely self contained. The <hr /> stands for a horizontal rule, a line across the page. == Search Engine Optimisation == Some tags are supposed to be used in certain locations on a webpage and have special functions that may not result in any change to the content or layout of that page. There are special tags reserved to help a webpage get found and ranked by search engines. These tags live in the <head>...</head> section of a webpage. *'''Come to my site first''' - this places a title on the top of the browser (NOT the top of a web page) *'''''' - so that search engines can better categorise web pages, they know what the site is about *'''''' - you used to be able to add keywords to tell search engines what a site was about. This was open to abuse as web site designers just chucked in all the words they could think of and this method isn't used much any more, however, you still need to know it. {{CPTExample|title=Example: Drawing a website}} Draw a web-browser display for the following: Kempoogle hello world! {{Webpage|Kempoogle|hello world!




 }} Notice that the <title>Kempoogle</title> appears as the title of the browser window, but the <meta name="Description" content="The best site in the world"> is not visible to the user. It is merely there to help web search engines categorise the page. {{Robox/Close}} {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: Web Site Basics}} {{CPTQuestion|What are the top most level tags on a website:}} {{CPTAnswer| and }} {{CPTQuestion|Write the code to create a webpage that has the banner title of "Moogle - shopping site" and has a meta description of "The best site in the world":}} {{CPTAnswer| Moogle - shopping site ... }} {{CPTQuestion|How might you use the section of a web page to increase the page's ranking in search engines?}} {{CPTAnswer|Adjust the and tags}} {{Robox/Close}} {{ExampleRobox|theme=6|title=Extension: Teach Yourself HTML}} The web is full of free resources to skill yourself up and there is nothing to stop you becoming a top notch web designer. The questions here are suitable to get you through this course with some added elements. If you want to get really good at the vaste array of web technologies out there you should be looking to teach yourself. A great place to get started is the [[w:w3schools|w3schools]] website where you can take courses in: * [http://www.w3schools.com/html/default.asp HTML] * [http://www.w3schools.com/js/default.asp Javascript], the programming language behind interactive websites If you want to learn about the code that builds dynamic webpages, including Facebook, check out: * [http://www.w3schools.com/php/default.asp PHP] {{Robox/Close}} == Block-level tags == Block tags allow you to give a tag attributes such as padding and margin. This allows you to insert tags into various parts of a page and rely on the other elements there to move to make space for it without worrying about overlap. The tags you need to know are: * <h#></h#> - headings * <hr /> - horizontal rules * <p></p> - paragraphs * <br /> - make a new
line, * <ol></ol> - ordered lists * <ul></ul> - unordered lists * <li></li> - list items * <div></div> - div === Horizontal Rule === <hr /> - puts a horizontal line across the page where ever you are, useful for breaking up pages Examples of horizontal rule Normal Text
Normal Text
Normal Text {{Webpage|Examples of horizontal rule| Normal Text ---- Normal Text ---- Normal Text

}} === Headings === <h#></h#> - heading tags make any text between the tags a heading, the higher the number (h#) the less significant the heading Examples of headings

Heading 1

Heading 2

Heading 3

Normal Text The code above produces the following: {{Webpage|Examples of headings| {{CPTh1|Heading 1}}

{{CPTh2|Heading 2}}

{{CPTh3|Heading 3}}

Normal Text}} For all following examples the html, body and head tags have been left out. This doesn't mean they don't exist and if you code it you must include them. {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: Headings}} {{CPTQuestion|1=Draw out what the following codes would produce:

Years

Year 12

Year 13

Staff

}} {{CPTAnswer| {{Webpage|--| {{CPTh1|Years}}

{{CPTh2|Year 12}}

{{CPTh2|Year 13}}

{{CPTh1|Staff}}

}} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=

Introduction

My Life

My Cats

My Dogs

Barry

Aubrey

Rex

Theories

Conclusions

}} {{CPTAnswer| {{Webpage|--| {{CPTh1|Introduction}}

{{CPTh2|My Life}}

{{CPTh2|My Cats}}

{{CPTh2|My Dogs}}

{{CPTh3|Barry}}

{{CPTh3|Aubrey}}

{{CPTh3|Rex}}

{{CPTh1|Theories}}

{{CPTh1|Conclusions}}

}} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write the code to produce the following headings: {{Webpage|--| {{CPTh1|Output Devices}}

{{CPTh2|Monitors}}

{{CPTh2|Speakers}}

}} }} {{CPTAnswer|

Output Devices

Monitors

Speakers

 }} {{CPTQuestion|1={{Webpage|--| {{CPTh1|Team}}

{{CPTh2|Goalies}}

{{CPTh2|Defenders}}

{{CPTh2|Midfield}}

{{CPTh2|Strikers}}

{{CPTh3|Rooney}}

{{CPTh3|Socrates}}

{{CPTh1|Stadia}}

{{CPTh2|Old Trafford}}

}} }} {{CPTAnswer|

Team

Goalies

Defenders

Midfield

Strikers

Rooney

Socrates

Stadia

Old Trafford

 }} {{Robox/Close}} === Lists === There are 2 types of list that you need to know, '''o'''rdered '''l'''ists (<ol></ol>) and '''u'''nordered '''l'''ists (<ul></ul>). Each has individual '''l'''ist '''i'''tems (<li></li>) that hold all the data. * Unordered Lists <ul></ul> * give you a list made up of bullet points
  • apples
  • oranges
  • pears
 the code above would give you: {{Webpage|Examples of unordered list| * apples * oranges * pears}}
  1. apples
  2. oranges
  3. pears
 the code above would give you: {{Webpage|Examples of ordered list| # apples # oranges # pears}} As you can see above the individual list items are contained within the <li></li> brackets. {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: HTML Lists}} {{CPTQuestion|Write HTML to create the following lists: * Geoffrey * Bungle * Zippy * George}} {{CPTAnswer|
  • Geoffrey
  • Bungle
  • Zippy
  • George
 }} {{CPTQuestion| # Wittgenstein # Augustine # Heidegger # Marcel }} {{CPTAnswer|
  1. Wittgenstein
  2. Augustine
  3. Heidegger
  4. Marcel
 }} {{CPTQuestion|1=What would the following code output:
  • Kierkegaard
  • Jaspers
  • Frankl
  • Rand
 }} {{CPTAnswer| * Kierkegaard * Jaspers * Frankl * Rand }} {{CPTQuestion|1=What is wrong with the following code to print an ordered list:
  • Kierkegaard
  • Jaspers
  • Frankl
  • Rand
    •  }} {{CPTAnswer| the following code is corrected with comments
    1. Kierkegaard
    2. Jaspers
    3. Frankl
    4. Rand
     }} {{Robox/Close}} === Breaking pages up === A '''Div''' element is used to divide a web page into sections <div></div> - this takes up space on a page and the page will appear larger the more of them you place in. A '''Paragraph''' <p></p>, allows you to structure your text like you would if you were writing an essay. A '''Break''' <br />, creates a new line. == Inline tags == These don't take up any physical space on the page (they don't cause a new line) and can overlap each other. They are: * <span></span> - break the page into sections but don't create new lines, * <strong></strong> - make text '''bold''', * <em></em> - make text ''itallic'', * <a></a> - create a [http://www.google.com link] or an [[#Structure_of_a_web_page|anchor]], ** <a href="http://www.google.com"> link </a> produces the following:[http://www.google.com link] * <img /> - add an image ** <img src="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Googlelogo.png" /> produces the following:
    [[File:Googlelogo.png|200px]] Let's take a look at a quick example: {{CPTExample|title=Example: HTML worked example}}

    Ditty

    I tell you naught for your comfort,
    Yea, naught for your desire,
    Save that the sky grows darker yet
    And the sea rises higher
    - G.K.Chesterton, The Ballad of the White Horse(1911)     The output of the above is as follows:
    {{Webpage||{{CPTh3|Ditty}}

    I tell you naught for your comfort,
    Yea, naught for your desire,
    Save that the sky grows darker yet
    And the sea rises higher

    ----

    - G.K.Chesterton, ''The Ballad of the White Horse'' (1911)

    }} As you can see the layout of the HTML code doesn't always reflect how it will look on screen, remember even if your code looks like it has line breaks, if you don't use block-level tags such as <br /> or a <p> you won't get any breaks. {{Robox/Close}} Now it's time to test your knowledge: {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: Inline Tags}} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write the code to produce the following output: :''Hello'' '''how''' are '''''you'''''? }} {{CPTAnswer| Hello how are you? }} {{CPTQuestion|:'''I'm''' ''fine''
    thank you}} {{CPTAnswer| I'm fine
    thank you     }} {{CPTQuestion|:This is a [http://www.bbc.co.uk link] to the ''bbc website''.}} {{CPTAnswer| This is a link to the bbc website. }} {{CPTQuestion| The Quick Brown Fox Jumped over the Lazy Dog}} {{CPTAnswer|

    The Quick Brown Fox

    Jumped over the Lazy Dog

     }} {{CPTQuestion| * ''Bold'' * '''Link to google''' * [http://www.google.com Itallic] }} {{CPTAnswer| {apologies for the trick question!}
    • Bold
    • Link to google
    • Itallic
     }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write the code to create the following page linking an image called cat.jpg {{Webpage|Cat picture|This is a picture of a ''cat'':
    [[File:Cat Briciola with pretty and different colour of eyes.jpg|200px]]}} }} {{CPTAnswer| Cat picture This is a picture of a cat:
     }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write the code to create the following page linking an image called dog.jpg to the page http://college.ac.uk {{Webpage|Dog picture|This picture of a '''dog''' links to my college's website:
    [[File:Siberian Husky heterchromia edit.jpg|200px]]}} }} {{CPTAnswer| Dog picture This picture of a dog links to my college's website:
     }} {{CPTQuestion|1=What does the following code produce: The invention
    of weights and measures
    Makes robbery easier
    - Chuang Tzu     Quoted from: Merton, Thomas. (1969). The Way of Chuang Tzu. New York: New Directions. }} {{CPTAnswer| {{Webpage| |The invention
    of weights and measures
    Makes robbery easier
    ---- ''- Chuang Tzu''}} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=

    Modern art has taken the wrong turn in abandoning the search for the
    meaning of existence
    in

    order to affirm the value of the individual for his own sake

    - Andrei Tarkovsky

     Quoted from: Tarkovsky, Andrei (1989). Sculpting in Time. University of Texas Press }} {{CPTAnswer| note that the line breaks at the end of each line of code has no effect, we only place line breaks with <br /> and <p> {{Webpage| |''Modern art has taken the wrong turn in abandoning the search for the
    meaning of existence''
    in order to affirm the value of the individual for his own sake ''- Andrei Tarkovsky''}} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write the full html page code for the following webpage: {{Webpage|Car heaven| {{CPTh3|Car heaven}}

    Welcome to ''the'' car site

    *Cars *Vans *Bikes

    This week 30% discount

    }} }} {{CPTAnswer| Car heaven

    Car heaven

    Welcome to the car site

    • Cars
    • Vans
    • Bikes

    This week 30% discount

     }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write the full html page code for the following webpage, where the image address is: contempt.jpg with alt text of contempt and the web address is: http://bbc.co.uk {{Webpage|Education| {{CPTh3|Contempt}} without a gentle '''contempt''' for education,
    no gentleman's education is complete
    [[File:PSM V36 D704 Facial expression of contempt.jpg|200px]]
    Learn more Click [http://bbc.co.uk here] to learn more }} }} {{CPTAnswer| Education

    Contempt

    without a gentle contempt for education,
    no gentleman's education is complete

    Learn More

    Click here to go to learn more

     }} {{Robox/Close}} == Comments == Sometimes you want to write something in the HTML code of a webpage to help you understand the code better. This is called a comment and is an ubiquitous feature in any computing language. Comments don't perform any computing function and don't display on a finished Web page, they are merely there for the web designer to use so that they can understand the page better. For HTML we use the following tags: Love

    What Love is

    "Love means to love that which is unlovable; or it is no virtue at all."     In the example above, the line starting with the and ending in −−> is a comment. A comment block start with and ends with > and you can have as many comments as you like between those tags, as long as they start and end with −−. Everything in between these comment tags will not be displayed on the screen, producing this: {{Webpage|Love| {{CPTh3|What Love is}} "Love means to love that which is unlovable; or it is no virtue at all."

    }} {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: Comments}} {{CPTQuestion|1=For the following code sketch what it outputs: Friendship

    Hello

    Can I be your friend?

    1. Yes
    2. No
     }} {{CPTAnswer| {{Webpage|Friendship| {{CPTh3|Hello}} Can I be your friend? # Yes # No }} }} {{Robox/Close}} {{ExampleRobox|theme=6|title=Extension: HTML 5}} [[File:HTML5-logo.svg|thumb|center|100px]] What we have been learning so far are the very basics of web design. If you like what you've been doing you better check out HTML5. HTML5 is starting to make websites fully interactive with the ability to quickly embed videos and interact with web pages. Over the next few years you'll increasingly see applications moving over to this new technology, so get with the program and start learning at [http://www.w3schools.com/html5/default.asp w3schools]. {{Robox/Close}} {{BookCat}}

page.title: A-level Computing/AQA/Computer Components, The Stored Program Concept and the Internet/Webpage Design/HTML & style sheets

revision.comment: Rejected the last text change (by [[Special:Contributions/46.18.178.20|46.18.178.20]]) and restored revision 2599493 by Pluke
revision.text:
{{CPTPageNavigationU2| | Prev = Web page construction | Next = Webpage design}} {{displaytitle|title=Webpage Design: HTML & style sheets}} {{Dbox|[[Cascading Style Sheets|Style sheet]]|a collection of rules about how to present an HTML document}} In HTML it is possible to add colours, fonts and other styles to the web pages that you build, however this is not recommended and '''HTML should be used for structure only'''. To add colours, fonts, etc. we will use Cascading Style Sheets, also known as CSS. == Style rule == A style sheet is made up of Style Rules. Each Style Rule has three parts, a selector, a property and a value: {{CPTRuleTab}} selector {property : value} {{CPTRuleEnd}} For multiple properties you separate them using a semicolon; {{CPTRuleTab}} selector {property1 : value1; property2 : value2} {{CPTRuleEnd}} == Selectors == {{Dbox|selectors| "select" the elements on an HTML page that are affected by the style rule(s)}} selector {property : value} You need to know three types of selector: * '''type''', selects all elements of a certain type on the page e.g. h1 { color : green} selects all the heading 1s and turns them green * '''class''', selects all elements of the class you have specified and applies the style to only those elements .classname { color : red} * '''ID''', selects the item with the single ID that you have specified #idname { color : blue }. You can only apply an ID once in an HTML document {| class="wikitable" |- ! CSS Property !! Description !! CSS Values !! Example for Heading 1 !! Output |- | font-style: || Changes the font style of text elements || normal, italic, oblique || h1 { font-style : italic } || ''Hello'' |- | font-weight: || Define how bold text is || bold, normal, 400 || h1 { font-weight : bold } || '''Hello''' |- | background-color: || Define page or item background colour || green, brown, yellow || h1 { background-color : yellow } || Hello |- | text-align: || horizontal position of text || center, left, right || h1 { text-align : center } ||
Hello
|- | font-family: || define the font of page text || "Times New Roman", Arial, Helvetica || h1 { font-family : "Times New Roman" } || Hello |- | font-size: || define the size of page text || 100%, 250%, 50% || h1 { font-size : 250% } || {{CPTh2|Hello}} |- | color: || changes the foreground colour of an element || green, brown, orange || h1 { color : green } || Hello |- | (EXTENSION) text-decoration: || Allows for underlining, strikethrough etc. || overline, underline, line-through || h1 { text-decoration : underline } || Hello |} {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: CSS rules}} {{CPTQuestion|Write CSS rules to do the following:
Turn all heading 3s blue:}} {{CPTAnswer| h3 { color : blue} }} {{CPTQuestion|Turn all paragraphs red and itallic:}} {{CPTAnswer| p { color : red; font-style : italic} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Turn all class=bbold: bold and blue}} {{CPTAnswer| .bbold { color : blue; font-weight: bold} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Turn all class=uit: underlined and italic}} {{CPTAnswer| .uit { text-decoration : underline; font-style : italic } }} {{CPTQuestion|Name the three components of a CSS style rule:}} {{CPTAnswer| selector {property: value} }} {{CPTQuestion|Name the three different types of selector and describe each:}} {{CPTAnswer| * '''type''', selects all elements of a certain type on the page e.g. h1 { color : red} * '''class''', selects all elements of the class you have specified and applies the style to only those elements .classname { color : white} * '''ID''', selects the item with the single ID that you have specified #idname { color : blue} }} {{CPTQuestion|Describe the difference between HTML and CSS:}} {{CPTAnswer| * '''HTML''' - Used for page structure * '''CSS''' - a collection of rules about how to present an HTML document }} {{Robox/Close}} === Type === {{Dbox|Type rules|select all elements of a certain type on the page and apply styles to them}}
h1 { color : green }
Take the HTML behind a simple website: My Website

Welcome

This is my amazing website, look how great it is!

I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web.

Seriously!

 As we probably know, this would build the following page: {{Webpage|My Website|{{CPTh1|Welcome}}

This is my amazing website, look how great it is! I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web. Seriously!}} You might think my claims are a little over the top, but we could try to make the site better by adding some colour to the title using the following CSS rules: h1 { color : green } p { color : red; font-style : italic } We can't just place this directly into the page, we have to create a new section inside the tags, this is called embedding CSS, we'll look at another method, External Style Sheets later: My Website

Welcome

This is my amazing website, look how great it is!

I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web.

Seriously!

 What this will do is change the heading to green, and change each paragraph to red and italic: {{Webpage|My Website|{{CPTh1|Welcome}}

 ''This is my amazing website, look how great it is!'' ''I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web.'' ''Seriously!''}} {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: CSS Type Selectors}} {{CPTQuestion|1=For the HTML code below, show what the output would be for each set of CSS rules: My Website2

Contact Details

Please use the details below to get in contact

Telephone

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101

Email

1010101@10100101.com

 What would these two rules produce? h2 { color : red } h1 { color : blue; text-decoration : underline } }} {{CPTAnswer| {{Webpage|My Website2|{{CPTh1|Contact Details}}

{{CPTh2|Telephone}}

Please use the details below to get in contact
Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101 {{CPTh2|Email}}

1010101@10100101.com}} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=What would these two rules produce? p { font-weight : bold } h1 { font-style : italic } }} {{CPTAnswer| {{Webpage|My Website2|''{{CPTh1|Contact Details}}''

{{CPTh2|Telephone}}

'''Please use the details below to get in contact'''
'''Home: 0101010101010'''
'''Mobile: 1010101010101''' {{CPTh2|Email}}

'''1010101@10100101.com'''}} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write rules to produce the following output: {{Webpage|My Website2|{{CPTh1|Contact Details}}

{{CPTh2|Telephone}}

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101 {{CPTh2|Email}}

1010101@10100101.com}} }} {{CPTAnswer| h1 { color : red; } h2 { text-decoration : underline} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write rules to produce the following output: {{Webpage|My Website2|{{CPTh1|Contact Details}}

{{CPTh2|Telephone}}

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101 {{CPTh2|Email}}

1010101@10100101.com}} }} {{CPTAnswer| h1 { background-color : yellow; } h2 { text-decoration : underline } p { background-color : red} }} {{Robox/Close}} === Class === {{Dbox|Class rules|select all elements of the class you have specified and applies the style to only those elements}}
.classname {property1 : value1; property2 : value2}
Take another look at the HTML behind a simple website: My Website

Welcome

This is my amazing website, look how great it is!

I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web.

Seriously! As you can see there are classes attached to some of the HTML tags, namely the 'textb' and 'texts' classes. On their own they don't do anything, we need to write some CSS style rules to make them come to life, remember that a class selector starts with a (.). .textb { color : red; text-decoration : underline } .texts { font-style : italic } {{Webpage|My website2|{{CPTh2|Welcome}}

 This is my amazing website, look how great it is! ''I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web.'' Seriously!}} {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: CSS Class Selectors}} {{CPTQuestion|1=For the HTML code below, show what the output would be for each set of the CSS rules: My Website3

Contact Details

Please use the details below to get in contact

Telephone

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101

Email

1010101@10100101.com

 What would these two rules produce? .txtg { color : blue } }} {{CPTAnswer|1= note that class="txtt" does nothing as the CSS doesn't define it. {{Webpage|My Website3|{{CPTh1|Contact Details}}

{{CPTh2|Telephone}}

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101 {{CPTh2|Email}}

1010101@10100101.com}} }} {{CPTQuestion|1= .txtg { color : red } .txtt { text-decoration : underline; color : green } }} {{CPTAnswer| {{Webpage|My Website3|2={{CPTh1|Contact Details}}

{{CPTh2|Telephone}}

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101 {{CPTh2|Email}}

1010101@10100101.com}} }} {{Robox/Close}} === ID === {{Dbox|ID rules|select the item with the single ID that you have specified. '''You can only apply an ID once in an HTML document.'''}}
#idname { color : blue }
Take yet another look at the HTML behind a simple website: A Website

Welcome

This is my amazing website, look how great it is!

I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web.

Seriously! As you can see, I have assigned an id to each of the paragraphs, this means that I can now style them separately from each other. Remember that an ID selector starts with a #. #para1 { color : red } #para2 { color : white } #para3 { color : blue } {{Webpage|A Website| {{CPTh1|Welcome}}

This is my amazing website, look how great it is! I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web. Seriously!}} Each id rule applies to a different paragraph, unfortunately I set #para2 to white, so you can't see it! {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: CSS ID Selectors}} {{CPTQuestion|1=For the HTML code below, show what the output would be for each set of the CSS rules: My Website3

Contact Details

Please use the details below to get in contact

Telephone

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101

Email

1010101@10100101.com

 What would these two rules produce? #main{ color : green } #txthighlight{ background-color : yellow } }} {{CPTAnswer| {{Webpage|My Website3| {{CPTh1|Contact Details}}

{{CPTh2|Telephone}}

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101 {{CPTh2|Email}}

1010101@10100101.com}} }} {{CPTQuestion|1=Write the CSS to produce the following: {{Webpage|My Website3|2= ''{{CPTh1|Contact Details}}''

{{CPTh2|Telephone}}

Home: 0101010101010
Mobile: 1010101010101 {{CPTh2|Email}}

1010101@10100101.com
}} }} {{CPTAnswer| #main{ font-style : italic } #txthighlight{ text-align : center } }} {{Robox/Close}} == Style sheets (Cascading Style Sheets or CSS) == You should be pretty comfortable with the use of CSS rules, we are now going to look how these rules are linked with the HTML. As we know the style (CSS) of a web page’s contents should to be separated from its structure (HTML), and when these two things come together, it creates the page that you see in your web browser. There are two methods of linking style to structure that you need to know: * '''Embedded style''', blocks of CSS information inside the HTML document * '''External style sheets''', i.e., a separate CSS file referenced from the HTML document === Embedded style === Blocks of CSS information inside the HTML document. You can see that inside the head tag we have a block of CSS that applies to the HTML below it: My Website

Welcome

This is my amazing website, look how great it is! I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web. Seriously! === External style sheets === External style sheets use a separate file to store the style information (a .css file) and link the file from inside the HTML document. ----
home.html
---- My Website

Welcome

This is my amazing website, look how great it is! I doubt you could find a better one anywhere on the web. Seriously! ----
style.css
---- h1 { font-weight : 900 } .highlight {color : yellow } ---- As you can see above the HTML file links to the CSS file through the line:. You could get an HTML page to link to multiple CSS files and link a CSS file from multiple HTML files. [[File:CPT-Web-CSS-external.svg|center|300px]] External style sheets are a better way of linking CSS to HTML than embedding CSS in HTML as you can: {{Plus|Link one CSS file to many HTML files to reuse the same style without needing to retype it}} {{Plus|When changing the style of a website you only need to change the style information in one location and it'll filter through to all pages}} {{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: Types of style sheet}} {{CPTQuestion|Name the two different style sheets:}} {{CPTAnswer| * external * embedded * (there is also inline but it's not pretty to use and not in the syllabus) }} {{CPTQuestion|Why might you prefer to use external style sheets on a large web site?}} {{CPTAnswer|You can link the same style sheet from multiple pages and changes to the site style would only require changes to that one style sheet}} {{Robox/Close}} {{ExampleRobox|theme=6|title=Extension:CSS3}} [[File:Html5 css3 styling.svg|thumb|center|100px]] There is an awful lot more to learn about CSS and a new version is currently being released alongside HTML5. Don't get left behind, learn all about [http://www.w3schools.com/css/default.asp CSS2] and [http://www.w3schools.com/css3/default.asp CSS3] at w3schools. {{Robox/Close}} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: File:Einstein 1921 by F Schmutzer.jpg → File:Einstein 1921 by F Schmutzer - restoration.jpg
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:
Wikijunior Europe: {{SUBPAGENAME}}
}} == Europeans == [[File:Europe_orthographic_Caucasus_Urals_boundary.svg|thumb|250px|left|Europe]] '''731 million people live in Europe'''. The largest countries, by population, are Russia (143 million but many of these live in Asian parts of Russia) and Germany (80 million). The smallest countries, by population, are the [[../Holy See|Vatican City]] (1,000 inhabitants), [[../Monaco|Monaco]], [[../San Marino|San Marino]] and [[../Liechtenstein|Liechtenstein]]. == Religion == '''The major religion in Europe is [[Wikijunior:World Religions/Christianity|Christianity]]'''. Most countries in Europe have a majority of people who are Christian - generally Roman Catholic (most of southern Europe, central Europe and Ireland), Protestant varieties (the UK, Germany and parts of central Europe) and Orthodox (eastern and south-eastern Europe). Large minorities of [[File:Rectified_Languages_of_Europe_map.png|thumb|300px|right|Map of Europe showing the major languages]][[Wikijunior:World Religions/Judaism|Jews]] live in the UK and France (and [[../Poland|Poland]], Germany and central Europe in the past). [[../Turkey|Turkey]], [[../Albania|Albania]], [[../Kosovo|Kosovo]] and [[../Azerbaijan|Azerbaijan]] have majority [[Wikijunior:World Religions/Islam|Muslim]] populations with large numbers also in [[../Bosnia Herzegovina|Bosnia Herzegovina]] and [[../Russia|Russia]]. Several countries including [[../Czech Republic|Czech Republic]], [[../Estonia|Estonia]] and the [[../United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] have large numbers of people who [[Wikijunior:World Religions/Atheism|don't follow any religion]] == Languages == '''Over 100 languages''' are spoken today in Europe and many hundreds of others were spoken in the past. The [[../EU|European Union]] has 24 official languages although there are 28 countries in the EU. This is because some languages are spoken in more than one country. [[Wikijunior:Languages/English|English]] is spoken in the United Kingdom, [[../Ireland|Ireland]] and [[../Malta|Malta]]. [[Wikijunior:Languages/German|German]] is an official language in [[../Germany|Germany]], [[../Austria|Austria]] and parts of [[../Belgium|Belgium]]. [[Wikijunior:Languages/French|French]] is spoken in [[../France|France]] and Belgium. [[Wikijunior:Languages/Italian|Italian]] is spoken in [[../Italy|Italy]] and also in parts of [[../Slovenia|Slovenia]] and [[../Croatia|Croatia]]. The most spoken native EU language is German. English is spoken by more people as a second language than any other language in the EU. There are many languages in Europe which don't have large numbers of native speakers like [[Wikijunior:Languages/Manx Gaelic|Manx]] and Kashubian.


File:Einstein 1921 by F Schmutzer - restoration.jpg|Albert Einstein, scientist from Germany File:JohannesPaul2-portrait.jpg|Pope John Paul II from Poland File:Oscar_Wilde_Sarony.jpg|Oscar Wilde, writer from Ireland File:Gagarin_in_Sweden.jpg|Yuri Gagarin, cosmonaut from Russia File:David-Beckham3.jpg|David Beckham, footballer from the United Kingdom File:Croce-Mozart-Detail.jpg|Mozart, composer from Austria File:Pablo_picasso_1.jpg|Pablo Picasso, artist from Spain File:Tesla_circa_1890.jpeg|Nikola Tesla, inventor from Serbia File:Francesco_Melzi_-_Portrait_of_Leonardo_-_WGA14795.jpg|Leonardo Da Vinci, artist from Italy File:AlfredNobel2.jpg|Alfred Nobel, scientist from Sweden File:MustafaKemalAtaturk.jpg|Mustafa Ataturk, politician from Turkey File:Rita Ora 2, 2012.jpg|Rita Ora, singer from Kosovo
{| style="width:90%; margin:auto;" | style="vertical-align:top; width:20%;" | {{Template:WikijuniorEurope}} {{BookCat}}

Welcome, U3038613! {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on discussion pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * Learn how to [[Using Wikibooks|use Wikibooks]] and learn more about the community. * [[WB:CCO|Explore]], [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |}
Come introduce yourself in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room/General|general reading room]] or your project in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Projects|project reading room]]. If you have any questions, you can ask in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Assistance|assistance reading room]] or contact me personally.

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Rhannosh!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 21:27, 26 October 2011 (UTC)

Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 21:50, 26 October 2011 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Davidm1981!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 23:05, 26 October 2011 (UTC)

revision.comment: Removing "Group_of_smartphones.jpg", it has been deleted from Commons by [[commons:User:Fastily|Fastily]] because: [[commons:COM:DW|Derivative]] of non-free content.
revision.text:
==Introduction== Cell phones are used by prisoners to keep in touch with loved ones; however, they are also used to plan escapes, harm witnesses, and commit other crimes. As the number of cell phones in prisons continues to rise, it is important to understand the social impact this contraband has both inside and outside of prison. This chapter provides a brief history of the issue and evidence through case studies. It then examines the legislature concerning cell phone procurement and use in prison. In addition, the pros and cons of cell phones in prison are addressed by considering relevant social groups involved.
==History== Cell phones in prison have been declared [[W:Contraband|contraband]] because they allow inmates to continue committing crimes.<ref name="Cell Phones as Prison Contraband">[http://www.fbi.gov/stats-services/publications/law-enforcement-bulletin/july-2010/cell-phones-as-prison-contraband Cell Phones as Prison Contraband], FBI Article</ref> <ref name="Cellphones Thrive in Prisons">[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/us/03prisoners.html?_r=2 Outlawed, Cellphones Are Thriving in Prisons], New York Times Article</ref> While some prisoners use cell phones as a convenient, low-cost way to stay connected with family and friends, others use cell phones as a means to coordinate riots, drug deals, and other crimes both inside and outside of prison. <ref name="Cell Phones as Prison Contraband">[http://www.fbi.gov/stats-services/publications/law-enforcement-bulletin/july-2010/cell-phones-as-prison-contraband Cell Phones as Prison Contraband], FBI Article</ref> The introduction of the smartphone with its internet access to phone directories, maps and photos has increased the ease of intimidation, crime organization, and communication for prisoners.<ref name="Cellphones Thrive in Prisons">[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/us/03prisoners.html?_r=2 Outlawed, Cellphones Are Thriving in Prisons], New York Times Article</ref>
In the past 3 years, the number of cell phones found in federal prisons has more than tripled.<ref name="Illegal Cellphone Use by Federal Prisoners on the Rise">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/federal-eye/post/cellphone-use-by-federal-prisoners-on-the-rise/2011/09/07/gIQAb7wLAK_blog.html Illegal Cellphone Use by Federal Prisoners], Washington Post Article</ref> Between 2008 and 2010, the number of cell phones seized by the [[W:Federal Bureau of Prisons|Federal Bureau of Prisons]] increased from 1,774 to 8,656. <ref name="Illegal Cellphone Use by Federal Prisoners on the Rise">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/federal-eye/post/cellphone-use-by-federal-prisoners-on-the-rise/2011/09/07/gIQAb7wLAK_blog.html Illegal Cellphone Use by Federal Prisoners], Washington Post Article</ref> With such a drastic increase in the number of cell phones in 2 years, this growing security risk should be addressed through a variety of countermeasures and prevention techniques.
==Case Studies== ====Using Cell Phones to Coordinate Riots==== First Command of the Capital (PPC) is one of Brazil's largest prison gangs and uses cell phones to coordinate riots inside and outside the prisons of [[W:São Paulo|São Paulo]], Brazil.<ref name=" Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref> For example, in 2006, prison officials met to discuss the transfer of several inmates to a remote, high security prison to weaken PCC's power.<ref name=" Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref> A spy in the room who quickly relayed the information to the PPC. Within hours of the meeting, the PCC used cell phones to coordinate the prisoners and launch riots inside prisons and throughout Brazil.<ref name=" Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref> These riots lasted about a week, killing 170 people.<ref name=" Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref>
====Using Cell Phones to Intimidate Victims==== Richard Tabler, a convicted murderer on death row, used a cell phone to make a threatening call to John Whitmire, a Texas state senator and chair of the senate's Criminal Justice Committee. Tabler told Whitmire, "I know your daughters’ names. I know how old they are. I know where they live."<ref name="Deadly Weapon">[http://www.vincebeiser.com/pdfs/cellphones2.pdf Case Studies Involving Cell Phones in Prison], "Deadly Weapon" Article</ref> Whitmire called the state prison system's inspector general to express his concern as to how a prisoner accessed his number as well as his family's personal information.<ref name="Deadly Weapon">[http://www.vincebeiser.com/pdfs/cellphones2.pdf Case Studies Involving Cell Phones in Prison], "Deadly Weapon" Article</ref> In response, Governor Rick Perry ordered all state prisons to be locked down and all the inmates searched.<ref name="Deadly Weapon">[http://www.vincebeiser.com/pdfs/cellphones2.pdf Case Studies Involving Cell Phones in Prison], "Deadly Weapon" Article</ref> 128 phones and thousands of chargers, batteries and SIM cards were found.<ref name="Deadly Weapon">[http://www.vincebeiser.com/pdfs/cellphones2.pdf Case Studies Involving Cell Phones in Prison], "Deadly Weapon" Article</ref>
====Using Cell Phones to Arrange a Murder==== Carl Lackl witnessed a Baltimore murder and testified against the accused killer, Patrick Byers.<ref name="Deadly Weapon">[http://www.vincebeiser.com/pdfs/cellphones2.pdf Case Studies Involving Cell Phones in Prison], "Deadly Weapon" Article</ref> While awaiting trial in Baltimore's City Detention Center, Byers acquired a cell phone.<ref name="Deadly Weapon">[http://www.vincebeiser.com/pdfs/cellphones2.pdf Case Studies Involving Cell Phones in Prison], "Deadly Weapon" Article</ref> Byers obtained Lackl's name, address, and phone number and texted this information to an outside contact, offering $2,500 to "get rid of Lackl".<ref name="Deadly Weapon">[http://www.vincebeiser.com/pdfs/cellphones2.pdf Case Studies Involving Cell Phones in Prison], "Deadly Weapon" Article</ref> On July 2, 2007, this contact and a couple of accomplices brutally murdered Lackl with a .44 Magnum.<ref name="Deadly Weapon">[http://www.vincebeiser.com/pdfs/cellphones2.pdf Case Studies Involving Cell Phones in Prison], "Deadly Weapon" Article</ref>
==How Cell Phones get into Prison== ====Prison Guards==== The most common method of smuggling cellphones into prison is by bribing prison guards.<ref name="prisonguards">[http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/04/local/la-me-prison-guards-20110204 California prison guards union called main obstacle to keeping cellphones away from inmates], Los Angeles Times</ref> Guards will charge as much as $1,000 to smuggle in a phone and have been known to make $150,000 in a single year by smuggling phones to inmates.<ref name="prisonguards">[http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/04/local/la-me-prison-guards-20110204 California prison guards union called main obstacle to keeping cellphones away from inmates], Los Angeles Times</ref> Legislation has been passed recently to address this issue (see Legislation for Cell Phones in Jail). Despite this legislation, guards continue to supply inmates with cell phones. In November 2011, a correctional officer at the California Correctional Center in Susanville was found guilty of smuggling cell phones into prison in exchange for money. He faces a maximum statutory penalty of 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine.
====Hidden in other objects==== Prisoners have found many ingenious ways to smuggle cell phones into prisons. Some are carried in underwear or inside the prisoner's bodies. Others have been baked into loaves of bread, hidden inside packets of washing powder, concealed inside the soles of shoes, books or legal papers.<ref name="british smuggling">[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/moslive/article-1273197/How-smuggled-mobile-phones-used-prisoners-commit-crimes-cells.html How smuggled mobile phones are used by prisoners], Mail Online</ref> In England,the prison milkman Paul Donachy was arrested for attempting to smuggle mobile phones into Perth prison. It is claimed he inserted waterproofed phones into cartons of milk, which he then resealed. The cartons were delivered directly to the prison kitchen, where inmates with trustee status would retrieve them.<ref name="british smuggling">[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/moslive/article-1273197/How-smuggled-mobile-phones-used-prisoners-commit-crimes-cells.html How smuggled mobile phones are used by prisoners], Mail Online</ref>
====Thrown over prison walls==== Another increasingly popular method of smuggling cellphones into prison is by launching them over the walls of prison for inmates to collect during exercise periods. In some cases, friends of inmates use detailed satellite maps from the internet to work out the best place to throw the items so they won't be spotted by guards.<ref name="british smuggling">[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/moslive/article-1273197/How-smuggled-mobile-phones-used-prisoners-commit-crimes-cells.html How smuggled mobile phones are used by prisoners], Mail Online</ref> In Brazil, there have been cases of teenagers being hired to launch cellphones over walls using a bow and arrow.<ref name="Cell phones and bow and arrows>[http://forums.officer.com/forums/showthread.php?152525-Brazilian-teen-caught-shooting-cell-phones-into-prison-with-a-bow-and-arrow Brazilian teen caught shooting cell phones into prison with a bow and arrow], Officer.com</ref>
==Access denied==
====Body Scanning==== Body Scanners in prisons are used to reveal items hidden beneath clothing as well as in body cavities.<ref name="Inmates at Pasco jail now face body scan">[http://www.tampabay.com/news/publicsafety/crime/inmates-at-pasco-jail-now-face-body-scan-for-drugs-weapons/1197789 Inmates at Pasco jail now face body scan for drugs, weapons], St Petersburg Times Article</ref><ref name="Prison 'Fights' Cell Phones">[http://prisoncellphones.com/blog/2011/09/26/prison-fights-%E2%80%98cell%E2%80%99-phones/ Prison 'Fights' Cell Phones], meshDETECT Blog Post</ref> While body scanning has intercepted many attempts to smuggle cell phones into prison, they do not account for cell phones thrown over walls or smuggled in by guards who can avoid the scanner.<ref name="Cell Phones in Prison">[http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/welcome.htm Cell Phones in Prison], National Institute of Justice</ref><ref name="Cellphones Thrive in Prisons">[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/us/03prisoners.html?_r=2 Outlawed, Cellphones Are Thriving in Prisons], New York Times Article</ref>
====Dog Sniffing==== Dogs are trained to recognize and trace the scent of cell phones. This method has become particularly popular with jails because it is claimed to be more cost efficient and reliable than other cell phone detecting or jamming technologies.<ref name="Cell-phone sniffing dogs catch global attention">[http://washingtonexaminer.com/local/cell-phone-sniffing-dogs-catch-global-attention Cell-phone sniffing dogs], Washington Examiner Article</ref> However, one must consider the time and money it takes to train the dogs as well as the limitations associated with dog sniffing. For example, to find the phone, dogs must be close to the phone and evidence suggests that the phone must be left in the same place for a considerable time so the scent can accumulate.<ref name="Cell Phones in Prison">[http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/welcome.htm Cell Phones in Prison], National Institute of Justice</ref> This would not appear to be an efficient method for searching large jails.
====Jamming==== Jamming uses radio waves to block any radio signals in a defined area, thus preventing cell phones from working.<ref name="Cell Phones in Prison">[http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/welcome.htm Cell Phones in Prison], National Institute of Justice</ref><ref name="Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref> While this is an effective method for preventing prisoners from using cell phones, there are a number of safety and legal issues associated with jamming. Jamming is a non-specific technique that has been shown to block the signals of residents in the surrounding areas as well as interfere with emergency cell phone calls and police radios.<ref name="Cell Phones in Prison">[http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/welcome.htm Cell Phones in Prison], National Institute of Justice</ref> For example, a jammer used at a high school to prevent students from using their cellphones also disabled a nearby policeman's cross-band repeater.<ref name="Cell Phones as Prison Contraband">[http://www.fbi.gov/stats-services/publications/law-enforcement-bulletin/july-2010/cell-phones-as-prison-contraband Cell Phones as Prison Contraband], FBI Article</ref> Due to the ability of jammers to interfere with emergency calls and public safety communication, jamming is currently illegal in the United States.<ref name="FCC: Putting an End to Illegal Cell Phone Use in Prisons>[http://www2.fcc.gov/pshs/docs/summits/Combating-Contraband-Cell-Phones-in-Prison-Handout-v4.pdf Putting an End to Illegal Cell Phone Use In Prisons], Federal Communications Commissions</ref> Section 333 of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) Act of 1934 states “[N]o person shall willfully or maliciously interfere with or cause interference to any radio communications”.<ref name="Cell Phones in Prison">[http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/welcome.htm Cell Phones in Prison], National Institute of Justice</ref><ref name="Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref>
====Managed Access====
The managed access system is a method in which call signals are intercepted, not jammed, for a specific area. There are two modes for the managed access system: passive and active. During the passive mode, all devices in the area work normally while the system collects the identifying information. Once the information is collected, each phone is categorized as authorized or not authorized. During the active mode, only the authorized devices are allowed to connect to the network and function as normal, thus controlling who has access to working mobile devices.<ref name="Analysis of Senate Bill 26">[http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/pub/11-12/bill/sen/sb_0001-0050/sb_26_cfa_20110816_163530_asm_comm.html Analysis of Senate Bill 26], US Senate</ref> Unlike jamming, this system does not require any legal adjustments, and has been implemented in institutions in Mississippi, South Carolina and California.<ref name="Cellphones Thrive in Prisons">[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/us/03prisoners.html?_r=2 Outlawed, Cellphones Are Thriving in Prisons], New York Times Article</ref><ref name="Mississippi DOC Launches First Managed Access System In The U.S. by Deploying Tecore’s iNAC™ To Fight Contraband Cell Phones in “Operation Cellblock”">[http://www.prweb.com/releases/contraband_cell_phones/Operation_Cellblock/prweb4485614.htm Mississippi DOC Launches First Managed Access System in the U.S.], PRWeb</ref><ref name="FCC: Putting an End to Illegal Cell Phone Use in Prisons>[http://www2.fcc.gov/pshs/docs/summits/Combating-Contraband-Cell-Phones-in-Prison-Handout-v4.pdf Putting an End to Illegal Cell Phone Use In Prisons], Federal Communications Commissions</ref> The main drawback to this system would be if a cellmate had access to an authorized device.<ref name="Cell Phones in Prison">[http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/welcome.htm Cell Phones in Prison], National Institute of Justice</ref>
==Legislation for Cell Phones in Jail== The problem of cell phones in prison has developed in the past decade as the models become smaller and gain more functions.<ref name="Cell Phones in Prison">[http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/welcome.htm Cell Phones in Prison], National Institute of Justice</ref> For this reason, regulations for cell phones in prison are only just beginning to appear. All state and federal prisons in the United States have banned cell phones. Depending on the state, the penalties for an inmate having a cell phone vary from an increase in parole to new criminal charges.<ref name="Cellphones Thrive in Prisons">[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/us/03prisoners.html?_r=2 Outlawed, Cellphones Are Thriving in Prisons], New York Times Article</ref> In August 2010, President Obama signed into action the Cell Phone Contraband Act of 2010.<ref name="S. 1749: Cell Phone Contraband Act of 2010">[http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s111-1749&tab=summary Cell Phone Contraband Act of 2010], US Congress</ref> The bill amended the federal criminal code to outlaw the possession of cell phones by federal prisoners.<ref name="S. 1749: Cell Phone Contraband Act of 2010">[http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s111-1749&tab=summary Cell Phone Contraband Act of 2010], US Congress</ref> In October 2011, California's Governor Jerry Brown signed the Senate Bill 26 into action. The bill increases the penalties for an inmate possessing a cell phone, establishes the penalties for someone possessing a cell phone with the intent to deliver to an inmate, and permits state jails to implement the managed access system.<ref name="Analysis of Senate Bill 26">[http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/pub/11-12/bill/sen/sb_0001-0050/sb_26_cfa_20110816_163530_asm_comm.html Analysis of Senate Bill 26], US Senate</ref> If caught with a cell phone, the inmate could lose up to 90 days of sentence credit. A person caught intending to deliver a cell phone to an inmate will be charged with a misdemeanor, sentenced to up to 6 months in jail and/or fined $5,000 per cell phone. By implementing the manage access system, the jails obtain the right to intercept phone calls for inmates and any visitors during their visit.<ref name="Analysis of Senate Bill 26">[http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/pub/11-12/bill/sen/sb_0001-0050/sb_26_cfa_20110816_163530_asm_comm.html Analysis of Senate Bill 26], US Senate</ref>
==Social groups involved== ====Prison Guards==== Prison guards are directly in contact with the prisoners and play dual roles in the prevention and promotion of cell phone use in jail. They are responsible for checking prisoners and visitors when they enter prisons. They also survey the prisoners to ensure that mobile devices were not smuggled in some other way. The Access Denied section describes some ways cell phones have been prevented in prisons. Some more [http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/summarized-approaches.htm technological solutions] have also been explored by the National Department of Justice.<ref>"Cell Phones in Prison" (2011). National Institute of Justice. http://nij.gov/topics/corrections/institutional/contraband/cell-phones/</ref>
Contrarily, prison guards have been responsible for the delivery of some cell phones to inmates.<ref name="Cellphones Thrive in Prisons">[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/us/03prisoners.html?_r=2 Outlawed, Cellphones Are Thriving in Prisons], New York Times Article</ref> Guards' proximity to prisoners makes them easy targets to bribe in exchange for smuggling in cellphones (see How Cell Phones get in).
====Prisoners==== The prisoners have several reasons for wanting cell phones in prisons. Most prisoners use them to keep in touch with family and friends.<ref name="Cell Phones as Prison Contraband">[http://www.fbi.gov/stats-services/publications/law-enforcement-bulletin/july-2010/cell-phones-as-prison-contraband Cell Phones as Prison Contraband], FBI Article</ref> Although there have been suggestions in the past for landlines or prison phones that they can periodically use, the prisoners seem to prefer an exclusive or shared mobile phone because they want privacy and landlines are constantly monitored. <ref name="Cell Phones as Prison Contraband">[http://www.fbi.gov/stats-services/publications/law-enforcement-bulletin/july-2010/cell-phones-as-prison-contraband Cell Phones as Prison Contraband], FBI Article</ref> Also, prison authorities do not cover the costs of calls to landline, and hence the people calling prisoners have to pay for these calls.<ref name="Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref> Prisoners have also used the cell phones as a means to reveal the mistreatment and abuse they receive in prison from the guards. In one case in Los Angeles, the FBI slipped cell phones to inmates in the prison to perform a sting operation on the mistreatment in prison. <ref name="FBI probing reports of beatings in L.A. County jails>[http://articles.latimes.com/2011/sep/25/local/la-me-fbi-jails-20110925 FBI Probing Reports of Beatings in L.A. County Jails], Los Angeles Times</ref>
====Telephone Companies==== Telecommunications companies expressed resistance to jamming cellphones in prison for legal and safety issues (see Accessed Denied: Jamming). <ref name="FCC: Putting an End to Illegal Cell Phone Use in Prisons>[http://www2.fcc.gov/pshs/docs/summits/Combating-Contraband-Cell-Phones-in-Prison-Handout-v4.pdf Putting an End to Illegal Cell Phone Use In Prisons], Federal Communications Commissions</ref> Cell phone companies have argued against jamming because it blocks the use of phones for customers in the area who are not inmates, including prison authorities.
Many phone companies make a significant profit by forming contracts with prisons and charging much higher calling rates to prisoners. As a result, these companies are against cell phones in prison because prisoners would not use the landlines and the company's profits would drop. <ref name="Nationwide PLN Survey Examines Prison Phone Contracts, Kickbacks>[https://www.prisonlegalnews.org/%28S%2834xg4h553u305v453i4j5u45%29%29/displayArticle.aspx?articleid=23083&AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1 Nationwide PLN Survey], Prison Legal News</ref><ref name="Cell Phones as Prison Contraband">[http://www.fbi.gov/stats-services/publications/law-enforcement-bulletin/july-2010/cell-phones-as-prison-contraband Cell Phones as Prison Contraband], FBI Article</ref><ref name="Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref><ref name="Cell Phones in Prison: A Former Inmate Explains the real deal">[http://blogs.browardpalmbeach.com/pulp/2011/01/cell_phones_in_prison_a_former.php Former Inmate Explains the Real Deal], New Times Blog</ref> Prisons also often pair up with certain companies that charge an overpriced rate for calls in order to help the prison generate revenue.<ref name="Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/20/AR2006052001105.html Brazilian City Wakes to Prison Gang's Power], Washington Post Article</ref>
<references />
{{BookCat}}

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, HannahMeredith!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 23:48, 26 October 2011 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Manyagarg!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''

Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 23:48, 26 October 2011 (UTC)

salah satu cara membuat backlink adalah menggunakan backlinkboomber

Christian de Duve is a renowned biochemist and cytologist. De Duve was born on October 2, 1917 near London but being of Belgian descent, moved back to Antwerp,Belgium where he was educated by the Jesuits and later went to school at the Catholic University of Leuven. He is most well known for his studies in subcellular biochemistry and cell biology. He was attracted to studying medicine because of the appeal of having an occupation in the field of medicine.
He first started off his career in a laboratory under Professor J.P. Bouckaert, who greatly influenced his later career. De Duve's work in the laboratory was focused on discovering the effects of insulin upon glucose uptake in the body; therefore, by the time he graduated, de Duve's main primary goal was to elucidate insulin's mechanism of action. From that point on, his career was focused on the biochemical study of insulin.
He eventually became a professor in 1951 at Louvain, and headed a small research laboratory to answer the broader questions concerning insulin. In this lab, he accidentally discovered the "latency" of acid phosphatase while investigating carbohydrate metabolism in the liver. He abandoned his insulin focus, and decided to focus on his new discovery instead. Following this new focus in his career, de Duve was coined for discovering lysosomes and peroxisomes, cell organelles where digestive and metabolic processes take place. He found that lysosomes are the cell's digestive system, while peroxisomes are where crucial cell metabolism takes place.
In 1962, de Duve became a professor at Rockefeller University in New York and started another laboratory with the same general research interests as the first laboratory in Belgium. In 1974 he was awarded the Nobel Prize with his colleagues Albert Claude and George Palade for describing the structure and function of organelles in cells. In addition to contributing to the discovery of the structures inside cells, he studied the enzyme activity in rat liver cells using a process called rate-zonal centrifugation. These studies helped pave the way for further discovery into the function of cell structures.
<ref>http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1974/duve-autobio.html</ref> {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
== Join Us! ==
==Welcome!== [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome to Wikibooks]]! You do not need to [[WB:LOGIN|log in]] to read or edit books at Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: * A username of your choice for directly attributing [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|your contributions]]. * A personal user page, a [[WB:TALK|talk page]], and a [[Help:Tracking changes#Watching pages|watchlist]] to monitor pages that interest you. * The ability to [[WB:MOVE|rename]] pages and to [[WB:PREFS|customize]] some aspects of the Wikibooks interface. * People will recognize you as a member of the Wikibooks community, and you will be eligible to [[WB:REVIEW|review]] pages. * Your IP address will be hidden from most users, which may give you a greater sense of security and privacy.
We hope that you choose to join our community as a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]]. Be sure to sign your talk page comments with four tildes (<nowiki>~~~~</nowiki>).--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|<sup>talk</sup>]] 11:14, 27 October 2011 (UTC)
[http://fr.wikibooks.org/wiki/Utilisateur:Gzen92 Gzen92 (fr.wikibooks.org)]

=HYPERTENSION: Guidelines for Exercise Prescription=
==Hypertension: A life threatening condition==
Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is currently one of the largest causes of death in Australia<sup>(3)</sup>. A principal contributor to CVD, is Hypertension, also known as high blood pressure<sup>(5)</sup>. Hypertension is also a considerable risk factor for stroke, coronary heart disease, kidney disease and heart failure<sup>(1)</sup>.
Approximately 29% of Australians have hypertension<sup>(1)</sup>. The 2004-2005 Australian National Health Survey data demonstrated that the prevalence of hypertension increases with age, as 14% of those aged 45-55 years reported the disease compared to 41% of those aged over 75 years. It is believed that as the average population age increases, so will these figures<sup>(5)</sup>.
Currently the main form of treatment for patients with high blood pressure is the implementation of drug therapy and lifestyle modifications including dietary and physical activity<sup>(2)</sup>.
The classification of blood pressure levels is found in the following table.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Table 1: Classification of blood pressure levels<sup>(3)</sup> |- ! Category !! Systolic BP (mmHg) !! Diastolic BP (mmHg) |- | Normal || <120 || <80 |- | High-normal || 120-139 || 80-89 |- | Grade 1 (mild) || 140-159 || 90-99 |- | Grade 2 (moderate) || 160-179 || 100-109 |- | Grade 3 (server) || >180 || >110 |}
==The relationship between Hypertension and Physical Activity==
Epidemiologic studies demonstrate a strong relationship between physical inactivity and hypertension<sup>(1)</sup>. For this reason, physical activity is recommended as a first line of intervention in the prevention, treatment and control of hypertension<sup>(1,2,5)</sup>. According to the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM)<sup>(4)</sup>, the implementation of physical activity reduced the risk of developing hypertension with age by more than 30-50%. It is recommended for preventing and treating those with prehypertension and treating those with grade 1 and grade 2 hypertension.
The ACSM 2004 review<sup>(4)</sup> of the interaction between BP and exercise also suggests that there are a number of effects from physical activity. When in regard to endurance/aerobic exercise the following can be seen:
:* Acute/Short term effects: immediately after exercise there is an average reduction in BP of 5-7 mmHg, referred to as most as exercise hypotension. This affect regardless of exercise intensity may last up to 22 hours.
:* Chronic/Long term effects: with regular moderate endurance exercise lasting between 30 and 60 minutes individuals with hypertension not treated with drug therapy may reduce their baseline BP by 5-7 mmHg. Additionally individuals with normal baseline BP due to drug therapy may reduce BP further by up to 2.6 mmHg.
When in regard to resistance/strength training a favourable chronic effect on baseline BP is demonstrated, however it is important to note that these effects are lower than those demonstrated by endurance exercise<sup>(1)</sup>.
==Recommendations for Physical Activity==
====Precautions====
:* It is important to note that most patients with high-normal and grade 1 hypertension can safely participate in moderate exercise programs without thorough medical screening<sup>(1)</sup>; however it is recommended to seek medical advice before starting any physical activity program<sup>(3)</sup>. :* For those with grade 2 and 3 hypertension and those over 50 years of age, a stress test is recommended to analyse the hearts response to exercise<sup>(1)</sup>. Following this exercise should be prescribed by a certified clinical exercise physiologist<sup>(1,5)</sup>. :* When exercising monitor exertion and blood pressure levels closely<sup>(6)</sup>. Take breaks when required. :* A systolic BP higher than 220 mmHg and diastolic higher than 100 mmHg is considered abnormal when exercising<sup>(2)</sup>.
====Physical Activity suggestions====
:* Type: Aerobic physical activity of a moderate intensity, incorporating large muscle groups is the recommended treatment strategy for all individuals with hypertension. Examples include walking, jogging, bike riding<sup>(1)</sup>. :* Intensity: Physical Activity of a moderate intensity is the optimal level for those with hypertension<sup>(1,2)</sup>. This is considered as 50 – 60% of the individual’s maximum heart rate<sup>(1)</sup>, easily estimated with the following equation, 220 - age. :* Frequency: Physical activity should ideally be completed 5-7 days a week for at least 30-60 minutes. It is best to start and build up from 20 minutes of activity<sup>(1,2,4)</sup>. :* Other: Light resistance training may be beneficial and considered as an adjunct to aerobic physical activity<sup>(1)</sup>, especially within ageing populations<sup>(5)</sup>. However its effects are not as significant as aerobic physical activity. When resistance training is utilised individuals must not hold breath while lifting as this exacerbates the BP response to exercise<sup>(2)</sup>.
==Conclusion==
Physical Activity prescription is considered as a first line prevention and treatment for hypertension. The benefits of physical activity are in many cases shown to be similar to those of the drug therapy. It is important to note that physical activity should be prescribed under the appropriate precautions for all individuals.
==Recommended Reading==
[http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/719396 Exercising With Hypertension: Prescription for Health.]
[http://www.heartfoundation.org.au/SiteCollectionDocuments/HypertensionGuidelines2008to2010Update.pdf Heart Foundation Guide to management of hypertension]
==References==
# Baster, T., & Baster-Brooks, C. (2005). Exercise and hypertension. Australian Family Physician, 34(6), 419-424. # Chintanadilok, J., & Lowenthal, D. L. (2002). Exercise in treating hypertension. Active Living, 11(3), 12-13. # Heart Foundation. (2010). Guide to management of hypertension 2008. Australia: Retrieved from http://www.heartfoundation.org.au # Pescatello, L. S., Franklin, B. A., Fagard, R., Farquhar, W. B., Kelley, G. A., & Ray, C. A. (2004). American college of sports medicine position stand: Exercise and hypertension. / exercise and hypertension. Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise, 36(3), 533-553. # Sharman, J. E., & Stowasser, M. (2009). Australian association for exercise and sports science position statement on exercise and hypertension. Journal of Science & Medicine in Sport, 12(2), 252-257. # Wallace, J. P. (2003). Exercise in hypertension: A clinical review. Sports Medicine, 33(8), 585-598. Retrieved from http://www.adis.com

revision.comment: /* Consumer-to-Consumer (C2C) Business Model */ Removed extra "d" from the phrase "ad site" in first paragraph. Added paragraphs 2 and 3 as well as Land of Oz image.
revision.text:
[[File:Ebay.jpg|100px|thumb|left]] ==Consumer-to-Consumer (C2C) Business Model== The consumer-to-consumer (C2C), or sometimes called person-to-person (P2P) business model is individuals selling directly to other individuals, something like an online garage sale. This is usually done via an intermediary web site such as eBay or Craigslist. eBay is an online auction site where individuals bid against other individuals for goods and services, and Craigslist is an online classified ad site where consumers can purchase items for sale by other consumers. One advantage of C2C is that sellers can reach a large group of consumers, and vice versa. One disadvantage of C2C is no quality control on what is sold. {{BookCat}}
From the mundane to the exotic, eBay, by far one of the largest online auction sites on the World Wide Web today, offers a wide array of products and services. For a small fee an online auctioneer can post his products with a detailed description and photographs. The consumer then bids on a product and agrees to buy that product if the bid is accepted at the end of a specified time. Payments are typically made electronically through Paypal.
Positive feedback is something that the seller wants to have and consumers must look for. It is a way of not only relating your shopping experience back to the seller but also to future consumers who may visit the seller’s other sites.
[[File:AdvertisementPlayTheWoggleBugByLFrankBaum07021905.jpg|thumb|Even The Land of Oz can be found on eBay as evidenced by this newspaper advertisement from 1905]]
Reference: Morely, Deborah and Charles Parker. "Understanding Computers Today and Tomorrow" 13th Edition

This seems a bit like a personal essay more then a wikijunior section, it would be nice if we had a more detached description.
